title: Analysis_Example
text: document, demonstrate use Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC) package. : Install SECFC package GitHub. Load SECFC sample dataset. Calculate carbon emissions using built-SECFC function. Run linear regression see income predicts total carbon emissions. Create plot data using ggplot2.

what: Step 1: Download the package from GitHub
title: Analysis_Example
text: First, need install package GitHub. remotes installed yet, run install.packages("remotes") beforehand.
code: # Install the SECFC package from GitHub remotes::install_github("jianing-d/SECFC") #> * checking for file ‚Äò/tmp/Rtmp8wbp5Q/remotes1e852a8aa534/jianing-d-SECFC-181245a/DESCRIPTION‚Äô ... OK #> * preparing ‚ÄòSECFC‚Äô: #> * checking DESCRIPTION meta-information ... OK #> * checking for LF line-endings in source and make files and shell scripts #> * checking for empty or unneeded directories #> * building ‚ÄòSECFC_0.0.3.tar.gz‚Äô library(SECFC)

title: Analysis_Example
text: Load SECFC package, provides calc_total_emissions() function among others.

title: Analysis_Example
text: demonstration, assume use questionnaire_sample.rds contains survey responses (provided pre-loaded package).
code: # Replace the file path with your own dataset if necessary questionnaire_example <- SECFC::questionnaire_example  # Take a quick look at your data structure str(questionnaire_example) #> tibble [50 √ó 34] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ RecordedDate          : chr [1:50] "30/6/2024 22:38" "30/6/2024 22:39" "30/6/2024 22:40" "30/6/2024 22:40" ... #>  $ T_01_CarUsage         : num [1:50] 4 3 3 4 5 4 5 4 3 3 ... #>  $ T_02_CarType          : num [1:50] 3 3 2 3 3 3 3 3 2 3 ... #>  $ T_03_CarDistance      : num [1:50] 2 1 3 2 2 3 4 1 4 2 ... #>  $ T_04_PublicTransport  : num [1:50] 5 4 5 4 4 5 5 5 5 4 ... #>  $ T_05_PublicTransport  : num [1:50] 4 4 4 2 4 4 4 4 4 1 ... #>  $ T_06_AirTravelLong    : num [1:50] 2 1 1 1 1 4 2 1 1 1 ... #>  $ T_07_AirTravelShort   : chr [1:50] "7-10 flights" "More than 10 flights" "4-6 flights" "More than 10 flights" ... #>  $ T_08_LongDistanceTra  : num [1:50] 5 4 5 4 4 5 5 5 5 5 ... #>  $ PETS_4                : num [1:50] 0 0 4 1 5 1 1 0 0 1 ... #>  $ PETS_5                : num [1:50] 2 0 2 1 1 1 0 0 0 0 ... #>  $ E1_Electricity Usage  : num [1:50] 2 2 2 1 1 1 1 4 1 1 ... #>  $ EH_02_ElectricityBil_1: num [1:50] 300 79 153 73 107 181 80 130 132 27 ... #>  $ EH_05_NaturalGasBill_1: num [1:50] 59 46 0 27 47 20 0 80 0 27 ... #>  $ F_01_DietaryHabits_5  : num [1:50] 12 8 6 9 10 1 7 8 13 8 ... #>  $ F_01_DietaryHabits_6  : num [1:50] 0 0 2 0 4 0 0 0 1 1 ... #>  $ F_01_DietaryHabits_7  : num [1:50] 0 2 0 1 4 0 5 0 5 2 ... #>  $ F_01_DietaryHabits_4  : num [1:50] 5 5 3 7 11 7 2 14 7 8 ... #>  $ CL_01_ClothingPurcha  : num [1:50] 3 3 4 3 4 3 4 5 3 3 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_9     : num [1:50] 0 15 200 20 0 0 200 0 0 0 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_10    : num [1:50] 200 100 0 49 0 150 100 100 250 100 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_11    : num [1:50] 200 0 0 58 0 100 0 0 0 0 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_12    : num [1:50] 0 0 0 0 100 100 0 0 0 0 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_13    : num [1:50] 30 25 0 20 100 500 0 0 0 0 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_14    : num [1:50] 50 35 50 0 0 80 50 100 100 100 ... #>  $ CL_03_MonthlyEx_15    : num [1:50] 0 0 35 150 0 610 0 800 0 0 ... #>  $ SD_06_HouseholdSize_17: num [1:50] 4 1 1 2 4 4 1 2 2 1 ... #>  $ SD_06_HouseholdSize_18: num [1:50] 0 0 0 1 0 2 0 2 0 0 ... #>  $ SD_06_HouseholdSize_19: num [1:50] 0 0 0 0 2 2 0 0 0 0 ... #>  $ SD_07_Country         : chr [1:50] "United States" "United States" "United States" "United States" ... #>  $ SD_08_ZipCode         : num [1:50] 85255 47905 30506 95843 95901 ... #>  $ EH_03_ElectricityBil_1: num [1:50] 3600 948 1836 876 1284 ... #>  $ EH_06_NaturalGasBill_1: num [1:50] 708 552 0 324 564 240 0 960 0 324 ... #>  $ income                : num [1:50] 70011 42460 38100 55435 46043 ...

title: Analysis_Example
text: Now use calc_total_emissions() function SECFC estimate respondent‚Äôs carbon footprint based survey responses. returned data frame include new column called TotalEmissions.
code: carbon_total <- calc_total_emissions(questionnaire_example)  # Check the first few rows head(carbon_total) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 40 #>   RecordedDate  T_01_CarUsage T_02_CarType T_03_CarDistance T_04_PublicTransport #>   <chr>                 <dbl>        <dbl>            <dbl>                <dbl> #> 1 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           5.5            3             10                      5 #> 2 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           3.5            3              5                      4 #> 3 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           3.5            2             30.5                    5 #> 4 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           5.5            3             10                      4 #> 5 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           7              3             10                      4 #> 6 30/6/2024 22‚Ä¶           5.5            3             30.5                    5 #> # ‚Ñπ 35 more variables: T_05_PublicTransport <dbl>, T_06_AirTravelLong <dbl>, #> #   T_07_AirTravelShort <dbl>, T_08_LongDistanceTra <dbl>, PETS_4 <dbl>, #> #   PETS_5 <dbl>, `E1_Electricity Usage` <dbl>, EH_02_ElectricityBil_1 <dbl>, #> #   EH_05_NaturalGasBill_1 <dbl>, F_01_DietaryHabits_5 <dbl>, #> #   F_01_DietaryHabits_6 <dbl>, F_01_DietaryHabits_7 <dbl>, #> #   F_01_DietaryHabits_4 <dbl>, CL_01_ClothingPurcha <dbl>, #> #   CL_03_MonthlyEx_9 <dbl>, CL_03_MonthlyEx_10 <dbl>, ‚Ä¶

title: Analysis_Example
text: examine respondent‚Äôs income might predict total carbon emissions. basic linear model using built-lm() function.
code: model <- lm(TotalEmissions ~ income, data = carbon_total)  # Display summary statistics of the regression summary(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = TotalEmissions ~ income, data = carbon_total) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -6303.6 -2107.0    40.9  3024.8  6997.5  #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept) 8.730e+03  1.115e+03   7.828 4.01e-10 *** #> income      4.933e-02  1.621e-02   3.044  0.00378 **  #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 3600 on 48 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.1618, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1444  #> F-statistic: 9.267 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 0.003779

title: Analysis_Example
text: Finally, can visualize relationship income TotalEmissions using ggplot2. plot includes: Points representing individual respondents linear regression line (confidence interval)
code: # Load ggplot2 library(ggplot2)  # Define custom colors point_color <- "#4A6D8C"  # desaturated blue-grey for points line_color  <- "#2C3E50"  # deeper blue-grey for the regression line  lm_plot <- ggplot(carbon_total, aes(x = income, y = TotalEmissions)) +   geom_point(color = point_color, size = 2.8, alpha = 0.8) +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, color = line_color, linewidth = 1.2) +   labs(     title = "Income and Total Carbon Emissions",     x = "Annual Income (USD)",     y = "Total Emissions (kg CO2e)"   ) +   theme_classic(base_size = 14) +   theme(     plot.title   = element_text(face = "bold", hjust = 0.5, color = line_color),     axis.title   = element_text(color = line_color),     axis.text    = element_text(color = "black"),     panel.border = element_rect(color = "black", fill = NA, linewidth = 0.8),     plot.margin  = margin(10, 10, 10, 10)   )  # Print the plot lm_plot

title: Get Started
text: Install package

title: Get Started
text: Follow steps calculate survey-based carbon footprints using SECFC.

title: Get Started
text: installation, load package :
code: library(SECFC) #> Loading required package: tidyverse #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5 #> ‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1 #> ‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1 #> ‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1 #> ‚úî purrr     1.0.4      #> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ #> ‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() #> ‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

title: Get Started
text: Make sure dataset data frame tibble format. ‚Äôre using Qualtrics template provided, ensure variable names match exactly. example expected data structure: ‚úÖ Note following columns automatically generated export responses Qualtrics: ~StartDate, ~EndDate, ~Status, ~IPAddress, ~Progress, ~Duration (seconds), ~Finished, ~RecordedDate, ~ResponseId, ~RecipientLastName, ~RecipientFirstName, ~RecipientEmail, ~ExternalReference, ~LocationLatitude, ~LocationLongitude, ~DistributionChannel, ~UserLanguage
code: library(tibble)  data <- tribble(   ~StartDate, ~EndDate, ~Status, ~IPAddress, ~Progress, ~`Duration (in seconds)`, ~Finished, ~RecordedDate, ~ResponseId,   ~RecipientLastName, ~RecipientFirstName, ~RecipientEmail, ~ExternalReference, ~LocationLatitude, ~LocationLongitude,   ~DistributionChannel, ~UserLanguage, ~Q39, ~CL_01_ClothingPurcha, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_9, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_10, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_11,   ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_12, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_13, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_14, ~CL_03_MonthlyEx_15, ~F_01_DietaryHabits_5,   ~F_01_DietaryHabits_6, ~F_01_DietaryHabits_7, ~F_01_DietaryHabits_4, ~T_01_CarUsage, ~T_02_CarType, ~T_03_CarDistance,   ~T_04_PublicTransport, ~T_05_PublicTransport, ~T_06_AirTravelLong, ~T_07_AirTravelShort, ~T_08_LongDistanceTra,   ~EH_02_ElectricityBil_1, ~EH_03_ElectricityBil_1, ~EH_05_NaturalGasBill_1, ~EH_06_NaturalGasBill_1, ~PETS_4, ~PETS_5,   ~SD_06_HouseholdSize_17, ~SD_06_HouseholdSize_18, ~SD_06_HouseholdSize_19, ~SD_07_Country, ~SD_08_ZipCode,      "3/20/25 9:43", "3/20/25 9:47", "IP Address", "111.187.123.25", 100, 240, TRUE, "3/20/25 9:47", "R_3lENNCNKNsOdbgd",   NA, NA, NA, NA, 31.2222, 121.4581, "anonymous", "EN", "Yes, I accept to proceed to the study",   "7-12 times (About every 1-2 months)", 30, 250, 50, 0, 50, 100, 200, 7, 3, 4, 6, "5-6 days",   "Gasoline Vehicle", "11-50 km or 6.2-31 miles", "Weekly", "5-10 km or 3.1-6.2 miles", "1-3 flights",   "1-3 flights", "Monthly", 120, 1440, 50, 600, 1, 1, 2, 1, 0, "United States", 10001 )

title: Get Started
text: Now ‚Äôre ready calculate emissions. Choose functions depending whether want calculation results also process data.

previous_headings: How to Use SECFC > Step 3: Run Emission Calculations
title: Get Started
text: Calculate carbon footprint general consumption. process details:
code: cons <- calc_cons_emissions(data) #> ‚úÖ A new data frame 'data_cons' is now available in your R environment. cons_process <- calc_cons_emissions_process(data) #> ‚úÖ A new data frame 'data_cons_process' is now available in your R environment.

text: Calculate total carbon footprint across domains. process details: ‚úÖ Note following columns automatically generated export responses Qualtrics: ~StartDate, ~EndDate, ~Status, ~IPAddress, ~Progress, ~Duration (seconds), ~Finished, ~RecordedDate, ~ResponseId, ~RecipientLastName, ~RecipientFirstName, ~RecipientEmail, ~ExternalReference, ~LocationLatitude, ~LocationLongitude, ~DistributionChannel, ~UserLanguage

title: Survey Template
text: ensure accurate carbon footprint calculations, dataset follow Qualtrics-compatible format provide. Please change variable names unless update function internals. list key columns expected SECFC, along corresponding survey question descriptions:

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jianing Ding. Author, maintainer. Ziqian Xia. Author. Jinquan Ye. Contributor. Jinliang Xie. Author. Ka Leung Lam. Author. Nathaniel Geiger. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ding J, Xia Z, Xie J, Lam K, Geiger N (2025). SECFC: Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC). R package version 0.0.3, https://jianing-d.github.io/SECFC/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SECFC: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)},   author = {Jianing Ding and Ziqian Xia and Jinliang Xie and Ka Leung Lam and Nathaniel Geiger},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.3},   url = {https://jianing-d.github.io/SECFC/}, }

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: SECFC (Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator) transparent, open-source R package designed assist researchers environmental psychology survey-based carbon footprint estimation. provides modular structure makes easy calculate analyze emissions various domains consumption, food, housing, transport, pets. SECFC particularly suitable academic studies requiring reproducibility, transparency, process-level emissions output.

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: https://ziqianxia.shinyapps.io/secfc/

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: Twelve core functions estimate individual-level carbon footprint based survey data. Ô∏è Transparent processing: Choose total emissions detailed calculation steps. Designed survey data structure mind. Ideal environmental psychology, behavioral science, carbon impact studies.

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: SECFC contains twelve main functions, divided two groups:

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: functions calculate total emissions domain append one new column dataset: - calc_cons_emissions(): consumption-related emissions - calc_food_emissions(): food-related emissions - calc_housing_emissions(): housing-related emissions - calc_pet_emissions(): pet-related emissions - calc_transport_emissions(): transport-related emissions - calc_total_emissions(): total emissions across domains function: - Takes data frame input - Appends new column calculated emissions - Returns updated data frame prints results

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: functions provide detailed emissions breakdowns, appending multiple columns intermediate steps: - calc_cons_emissions_process() - calc_food_emissions_process() - calc_housing_emissions_process() - calc_pet_emissions_process() - calc_transport_emissions_process() - calc_total_emissions_process() function: - Adds multiple columns explaining step--step calculation - Enhances transparency research teaching purposes - Also returns prints final emission result

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: ‚Äôs simple example use SECFC package practice:
code: # Step 1: Load the package library(SECFC)  # Step 2: Load your dataset # Example: use "questionnaire_sample.rds" df <- readRDS("questionnaire_sample.rds")  # Step 3: Calculate carbon emissions by domain cons <- calc_cons_emissions(df)       # Adds consumption emissions food <- calc_food_emissions(df)       # Adds food emissions housing <- calc_housing_emissions(df)    # Adds housing emissions pet <- calc_pet_emissions(df)        # Adds pet emissions transport <- calc_transport_emissions(df)  # Adds transport emissions  # Step 4: Calculate total carbon footprint total <- calc_total_emissions(df)  # Optional: Use process-level functions to view detailed steps cons_process <- calc_cons_emissions_process(df) food_process <- calc_food_emissions_process(df) housing_process <- calc_housing_emissions_process(df) pet_process <- calc_pet_emissions_process(df) transport_process <- calc_transport_emissions_process(df) total_process <- calc_total_emissions_process(df)

title: The Survey-Embedded Carbon Footprint Calculator (SECFC)
text: questions, bug reports, suggestions, please reach : Jianing Dingjianing.research@gmail.com Tongji University Ka Leung Lamkaleung.lam@dukekunshan.edu.cn Duke Kunshan University Nathaniel Geigergeigern@umich.edu University Michigan Ziqian Xiaziqianx@stanford.edu Stanford University Jinliang Xiejinliang.research@gmail.com Tsinghua University

title: Questionnaire Example Data ‚Äî questionnaire_example
text: sample dataset containing responses global questionnaire. demo data provided playing calculator represents typical survey data expect . includes responses transportation, energy usage, dietary habits, clothing consumption, household demographics, lifestyle factors.

title: Questionnaire Example Data ‚Äî questionnaire_example
text: tibble 50 rows 33 variables: RecordedDate chr; Date time response recorded, format "dd/mm/yyyy HH:MM". T_01_CarUsage dbl; Self-reported level car usage. T_02_CarType dbl; Categorical indicator type car owned used. T_03_CarDistance dbl; Reported distance travelled car. T_04_PublicTransport dbl; Frequency rating public transport usage. T_05_PublicTransport dbl; Secondary measure public transport usage. T_06_AirTravelLong dbl; Frequency extent long-distance air travel. T_07_AirTravelShort chr; Categorical description short-distance air travel (e.g., "7-10 flights", "10 flights"). T_08_LongDistanceTra dbl; Measure long-distance travel means. PETS_4 dbl; Count rating related pet ownership (e.g., number pets). PETS_5 dbl; Additional measure related pet ownership. E1_Electricity Usage dbl; Self-reported electricity usage level. EH_02_ElectricityBil_1 dbl; Electricity bill amount (first measurement). EH_05_NaturalGasBill_1 dbl; Natural gas bill amount (first measurement). F_01_DietaryHabits_5 dbl; Score frequency related specific dietary habit. F_01_DietaryHabits_6 dbl; Score frequency another dietary habit. F_01_DietaryHabits_7 dbl; Score frequency another dietary habit. F_01_DietaryHabits_4 dbl; Score frequency another dietary habit. CL_01_ClothingPurcha dbl; Frequency quantity clothing purchases. CL_03_MonthlyEx_9 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 9). CL_03_MonthlyEx_10 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 10). CL_03_MonthlyEx_11 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 11). CL_03_MonthlyEx_12 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 12). CL_03_MonthlyEx_13 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 13). CL_03_MonthlyEx_14 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 14). CL_03_MonthlyEx_15 dbl; Monthly expenditure clothing (item 15). SD_06_HouseholdSize_17 dbl; Primary measure household size. SD_06_HouseholdSize_18 dbl; Secondary measure household size. SD_06_HouseholdSize_19 dbl; Tertiary measure household size. SD_07_Country chr; Country respondent. SD_08_ZipCode dbl; Zip code respondent. EH_03_ElectricityBil_1 dbl; Additional measure electricity billing amount. EH_06_NaturalGasBill_1 dbl; Additional measure natural gas billing amount.

title: Questionnaire Example Data ‚Äî questionnaire_example
text: Demo data generated use SECFC calculator. data reflects typical survey responses collected globally.
